Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of Natural Resource Dependence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates an issue of central importance to some communities, the choice between reliance on natural resource extraction versus reliance on alternative forms of development. Extractive forms of natural resource use have been declining in the United States for decades. In their place, non-extractive forms of natural resource development such as tourism, outdoor recreation, and amenity development have emerged as a possible new direction. In this project, the relationship between these alternative paths and economic outcomes including economic growth, poverty, and opportunity is analyzed. The object is to see when and how particular strategies as well as change between strategies are beneficial. Findings will inform decision making concerning these areas of the United States and so will enhance national welfare.

Data for this project come from combining U.S. Census, American Community Survey, and Bureau of Economic Analysis data for relevant counties in the United States from 1970 to 2017. In the analysis, the historical effect of county-level extractive and non-extractive natural resource development on income growth, poverty, and opportunity will be tested and compared using spatial fixed-effects econometric models to provide an evaluation of how natural resource development affects income and its distribution over time. These models will be used to identify empirical thresholds of dependence in order to develop classifications of extractive, non-extractive, and hybrid (i.e., both extractive and non-extractive) dependence. Subsequently, trends and transitions in socioeconomic well-being will be evaluated for extractive and non-extractive natural resource dependent counties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tom Mueller has completed research for his dissertation "The Effect of Natural Resource Dependence on Economic Prosperity in Rural America". During this funding period, he spent the year working on the three primary objectives outlined in his proposal, while also attending the two funded workshops on multi-level modeling and causal inference.

The final product of this research, his dissertation, provides a comprehensive theoretical and empirical analysis of rural natural resource dependence in the United States from 2000 to 2015. As a three-article dissertation, the outcomes of the work are comprised of three distinct contributions to sociology and society.

In the first paper, Mueller developed a theoretical framework of natural resource dependence in the United States. He argued rural natural resource dependence represents a special kind of dependency relationship, wherein rural, resource-rich areas form a dual-dependency upon both the global capitalist system and their local natural environment. Due to a contradiction between spatially fixed natural resources and the necessary free movement of capital, external interests and local elite ultimately use their power to pressure rural economies in directions outside the best interest of the rural community. While these interests were historically focused on natural resource extraction (e.g. mining, timber, agriculture), over the past 50 years non-extractive interests (e.g. tourism, real estate) have increasingly emerged in their place. He then argues that non-extractive interests, while pushing a different use of the resource base, do not fundamentally vary from extractive forms of development in their exploitative relationship with rural areas. This paper is available as a preprint on SocArXiv at DOI: 10.31235/osf.io/e4akp

In the second paper of the dissertation, Mueller tested the association between extractive and non-extractive natural resource development and rural American economic prosperity from 2000 to 2015. Research shows rural dependence upon natural resource development leads to decreases in economic prosperity. Natural resource development can be viewed in two main forms, extractive (e.g. oil and gas, mining, timber) and non-extractive (e.g. tourism, recreation, real estate). However, research has rarely examined both of these at once. Mueller tested the hypothesis that increasing levels of both forms of natural resource development were associated with diminishing benefits to economic prosperity— which was operationalized as per capita income, inequality, and poverty—in rural America from 2000 to 2015. Extractive development exhibited the expected relationships in remote rural counties, while non-extractive development did not and had a generally negative relationship with per capita income, a positive relationship with poverty, and no significant relationship with inequality. Ultimately, support for the hypothesis was limited. While this outcome is useful intellectually, it also provides policy-relevant evidence for future economic development in rural America. The paper is available as a preprint on SocArXiv at DOI: 10.31235/osf.io/5pcwm

In the final paper of the dissertation, Mueller presented a clarified definition of natural resource dependence, while also generating a typology and classification scheme for use in future research and policy. Natural resource dependence, although frequently invoked in natural resource sociology, has often gone undefined. Resource dependence is often treated as over-specialization in the natural resource sectors. However, the logic of over-specialization conceptually grounds dependence in negative economic outcomes. This means a one-dimensional typology of dependence based upon a threshold of development in the natural resource sectors does not appropriately capture the underlying concept. Mueller has addressed this ambiguity by defining natural resource dependence as over-specialization in the natural resource sectors. He then presented an ideal typology, which he termed the Natural Resource Community Typology, and a classification scheme for rural natural resource communities in the United States. The typology combines extractive and non-extractive natural resource activity and has two dimensions: the level of resource development and the level of economic prosperity. This results in six mutually exclusive categories, extractive specialized, extractive dependent, non-extractive specialized, non-extractive dependent, hybrid specialized, and hybrid dependent. He then classified counties from 2000 to 2015 and found that extractive dependence decreased over the study period and non-extractive dependence increased. The results of this classification are publicly available and the preprint of the outcomes is available on SocArXiv at DOI: 10.31235/osf.io/j5skm

This body of work, of which two papers have been conditionally accepted and one is in review, represents a theoretical and empirical intellectual contribution to the field of sociology, while also providing policy-relevant evidence which will have a broader impact on society. The results of the empirical analysis have the potential to foster more equitable and effective rural economic development policy, while the typology has the potential to complement and improve existing typologies used by the general public and government agencies such as the USDA.
